items.title: The Motor City Though the Camera Lens
items.abstract: An exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts focuses on local landscapes of streets and cars and the automobile culture of Detroit.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
items.abstract: Morphogenesis, from the Greek words morphê, for shape and genesis, for creation, refers to imitating evolution in developing designs.

items.title: New York City Ties Doctors’ Income to Quality of Care
items.abstract: A proposal affecting physicians in public hospitals represents a push away from the traditional model of rewarding doctors for the volume of the services they order.
keywords: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

items.title: Charting a Post-Pollution Path for Cities – From London, 1952, through Beijing, 2013
items.abstract: Facing epic smog, China charts a shift from coal to gas for Beijing, and beyond.

items.title: Intimate, Haunting Portraits of New York City Youth
items.abstract: The photographer (and model) Ethan James Green finds many of the subjects in his ongoing series of creatives on social media.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: At the Ready as New Yorkers Got Unbundled
items.abstract: Across her decades as a Manhattan coat-check clerk, Nina Rochelle saw all sides of the city’s personality in the daily flurry of furs and suedes and fleeces. And she got the summers off.

items.title: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
items.abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: New York City’s Poor Were Promised Half-Priced MetroCards. They’re Still Waiting.
items.abstract: New York City was scheduled to start a discount fare program for low-income riders on Jan. 1. But the rollout has been a bit of a mess.
keywords: Community Service Society of New York

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Says Wealth Is ‘in the Wrong Hands,’ Pledges to Redistribute It
items.abstract: In his State of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio offered progressive promises and a new ferry between Staten Island and Manhattan’s West Side.

items.title: Five Takeaways From Mayor Bill de Blasio’s State of the City Address
items.abstract: Sounding at times like a motivational speaker, the mayor vowed to keep working to improve New Yorkers’ lives while taking his message to a national audience.

items.title: Adrienne Adams Makes History as First Black N.Y.C. Council Speaker
items.abstract: Ms. Adams, who became speaker on Wednesday, will lead the most diverse City Council ever as New York tries to recover from the pandemic. She already faces battles with the mayor.

items.title: ‘American Urbanist,’ a Well-Timed Biography of a Man Who Reshaped City Life
items.abstract: Richard K. Rein’s book tells the story of William H. Whyte, a sociologist who wrote “The Organization Man” and helped to rethink how cities look and feel.
keywords: American Urbanist: How William H Whyte's Unconventional Wisdom Reshaped Public Life (Book)

items.title: How Remote Work Is Devastating New York City’s Commuter Rails
items.abstract: Before the pandemic, they relied on office workers, who spent up to $500 a month on tickets. At the M.T.A., those sales are down 75 percent.

items.title: After Urban Flight, Corporate Campuses Add a Taste of the City
items.abstract: Suburban headquarters are being redesigned to add more amenities that will integrate better with their communities and attract the skilled workers.

items.title: Could Detroit Become the Next Fashion City?
items.abstract: In bringing an exhibition of creative talent to New York, the fashion label Deviate wants to show that Detroit has more to offer than a quick hit of novelty for luxury giants.
